section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to build background, engage children through dance, and introduce vocabulary (blaze, rushed).
Begin Story Time by introducing the book and asking, Why was Rowan sad in the beginning of the story?
Read for enjoyment and understanding, noticing vocabulary in context.
Check understanding, differentiating as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Share inferences, predictions, or conclusions about a text; Use appropriate tone of voice.
Understand and use varied types of words.
Respond appropriately to spoken language.
Use regular and irregular past tense; Use pronouns.
Take another perspective.
Separate sentences into words.
Talk about roles and jobs of people in their community.
Show emerging proficiency on tasks requiring eye-hand coordination.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Challenge children to identify different vehicles in their community.
Guide children to talk about how these vehicles play an important role in a community.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: What vehicles do we know about? How do they help us?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: What kinds of vehicles do you see in that book? How does each vehicle help us?
What vehicle can you pretend to drive?
How can you sort those vehicles into different groups?
What vehicles could you draw? What shapes will you use?
What materials can you use to build a vehicle? Will it have wheels?
Can you find the letters to spell the words car and bus?
Can use blocks to make a vehicle? What kind of vehicle will you make?

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to share the Mind Builder take another perspective and introduce vocabulary (point of view, polite).
Begin Story Time by connecting the Mind Builder to A Fire Truck Named Red.
Read closely to notice and talk about the Mind Builder.
Offer an extended play opportunity.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Share observations about stories; Share inferences, predictions, or conclusions about a text.
Understand and use varied types of words.
Use pronouns.
Take another perspective.
Use perception to guide movement through space and interactions with objects and people.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Have children identify and explore the perspectives of people in pictures.
Challenge children to think about another person’s perspective.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: What vehicles do we know about? How do they help us?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Can you find a picture of a vehicle that helps us?
Can you show me how an airplane flies?
Can you show three vehicles that help us? How are they the same?
Can you write about a toy vehicle that you really like?
Can you make your favorite vehicle? Does it run on gas or on batteries?
What letters do you hear at the start of the words boat, truck, and vehicle?
Can you build a garage for some vehicles? How many vehicles will it fit?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. A Fire Truck Named Red by Randall de Sève, illustrated by Bob Staake. Text copyright © 2016 by Randall de Sève. Illustrations copyright © 2016 by Bob Staake. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Farrar, Straus and Giroux, an imprint of Macmillan Publishing Group, LLC. TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to share the comprehension skill Make a Connection and introduce vocabulary (scene, siren).
Begin Story Time by revisiting A Fire Truck Named Red and asking the guiding question, When Papa was a little boy, what did he imagine doing with Red?
Check understanding and differentiate as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Respond appropriately to spoken language.
Share inferences, predictions, or conclusions about a text.
Understand and use varied types of words.
Use pronouns.
Take another perspective.
Join two or more words to create a compound word.
Show emerging proficiency on tasks requiring eye-hand coordination.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Have children use the word scene to describe picture cards.
Encourage children to talk about scenes in their communities.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: What vehicles do we know about? How do they help us?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: How are the vehicles in your books the same and different?
Can you show me two different vehicles?
Can you compare the size of two vehicles? Which is smaller? How do you know?
Can you imagine a vehicle that talks? Can you write about it?
How many different vehicles can you name? Can you sort them by how they are the same and different? Can you draw and color two of them?
What letter makes the sound you hear at the beginning of the words scene and siren?
Papa and Red rescued the cat in a tall tree. Can you build a tall tree using blocks?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. A Fire Truck Named Red by Randall de Sève, illustrated by Bob Staake. Text copyright © 2016 by Randall de Sève. Illustrations copyright © 2016 by Bob Staake. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Farrar, Straus and Giroux, an imprint of Macmillan Publishing Group, LLC.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

large-group-materials.tg_materials-caption: Big Chart of Big Ideas:The Wheels on the Bus
Book: A Fire Truck Named Red

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to build background on vehicles and introduce vocabulary words (engine, wings).
Begin Story Time by connecting The Wheels on the Bus and A Fire Truck Named Red.
Read interactively and connect to this week’s concept question, What vehicles do we know about? How do they help us?
Offer an extended play opportunity.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Share inferences, predictions, or conclusions about a text.
Understand and use varied types of words.
Respond appropriately to spoken language.
Use possessives.
Describe and sort objects by similarities and differences.
Identify, investigate, talk about, and describe the location and movement of common objects.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Help children identify vehicles that travel on land and vehicles that do not travel on land.
Invite them to identify vehicles that have a siren.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: What vehicles do we know about? How do they help us?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Which vehicle do you think helps us the most? Why?
What would be the best car in the world? What would it do?
Compare how two vehicles are the same and different.
Which vehicles would help a farmer? Can you write about them?
Can you use clay or paper to make a vehicle with wings?
Can you show me what letter makes the beginning sound you hear in the word wings?
Can you build a big bus? How big will it be? Show me.

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. A Fire Truck Named Red by Randall de Sève, illustrated by Bob Staake. Text copyright © 2016 by Randall de Sève. Illustrations copyright © 2016 by Bob Staake. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Farrar, Straus and Giroux, an imprint of Macmillan Publishing Group, LLC.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to have children act out scenes from A Fire Truck Named Red and to introduce vocabulary words (tanks, traffic).
Begin Story Time by revisiting the book and asking, What did Rowan think about Red at the end of the story?
Read and retell interactively for physical engagement and imagination.
Check understanding and differentiate as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Tell or retell stories.
Understand and use varied types of words; Understand and use a growing number of common phrases.
Respond appropriately to spoken language.
Use regular and irregular past tense.
Take another perspective.
Act out to recreate and retell stories, mood, or experiences.
Master basic skills of running, climbing, jumping, and pedaling.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Support children as they independently respond to this week’s prompt: Can you tell a story about a vehicle like Red? What is your vehicle’s name? What do you do together?
Differentiate and modify as needed.
Save children’s writing to display next week.

section-block.tg_essential-question: What vehicles do we know about? How do they help us?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: If you wrote your own book about vehicles that help us, what would you put in it?
Can you pretend to be driving a fire truck in traffic?
Can you compare the size of three toy vehicles? Which is the biggest?
Can you create a story about a car that can fly?
What are the different parts of a car? Can you make those parts?
What sound does the letter B make? Can you write the letter B?
Why did you use those materials to make the car parts? What do you like about them?

Illustrations copyright © 2016 by Bob Staake. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Farrar, Straus and Giroux, an imprint of Macmillan Publishing Group, LLC.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Investigate and demonstrate growing understanding of the sounds and intonation of language.
Use a large speaking vocabulary, adding several new words daily.
Match language to social contexts.
Use a large speaking vocabulary.
Demonstrate understanding in a variety of ways.
Use regular and irregular plurals and personal and possessive pronouns.
Demonstrates an understanding that others have perspectives and feelings that are different from own.
Separate a normally spoken four-word sentence into individual words.
Show increasing eye-hand coordination.
Demonstrate understanding of terms used in the instructional language of the classroom.
Match language to social contexts.
Demonstrate understanding in a variety of ways.
Use regular and irregular plurals and personal and possessive pronouns.
Demonstrate an understanding that others have perspectives and feelings that are different from her own.
Coordinate sequence of movements to perform tasks.
Use a large speaking vocabulary, adding several new words daily.
Demonstrate understanding in a variety of ways.
Use regular and irregular plurals and personal and possessive pronouns.
Demonstrate an understanding that others have perspectives and feelings that are different from her own.
Combine words to make a compound word.
Show increasing control of tasks that require eye-hand coordination.
Use a large speaking vocabulary, adding several new words daily.
Demonstrate understanding in a variety of ways.
Use possessives.
Sort objects that are the same and different into groups and use language to describe how the groups are similar and different.
Observe, investigate, describe, and discuss position and motion of objects.
Use a large speaking vocabulary, adding several new words daily.
Use a wide variety of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions.
Use a wide variety of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions.
Demonstrate understanding in a variety of ways.
Use regular and irregular past tense.
Demonstrate an understanding that others have perspectives and feelings that are different.
Create or recreate stories, moods, or experiences through dramatic representations.
